question:
A 35-year-old HIV positive¦ patient presents with mucosal lesions in the mouth as shown in the image below. on microscopy, budding yeasts and pseudohyphae are seen. what is the
likely diagnosis?
options:
a)oral candidiasis
b)Hairy leukoplakia
c)Lichen planus
d)Diphtheria
solution:
An HIV patient with white patches over the tonsils and posterior pharynx showing budding yeasts and pseudohyphae on microscopy suggests a diagnosis of oral candidiasis.
oral candidiasis or thrush is a patchy, pseudomembranous lesion that develops over the tongue, lips, gum or palate. It is composed of epithelial cells, yeasts, and pseudohyphae and can be
scraped off. The causative agent is usually candida albicans. It occurs in almost all individuals    with AIDS. other risk factors include hyperglycemia, cellular immunodeficiency, corticosteroids or antibiotics. It is treated with topical nystatin, oral ketoconazole or fluconazole.
option B: Hairy leukoplakia is a wart-like growth on the tongue, caused by Epstein-Barr virus. It is commonly seen as a white lesion on the lateral side of the tongue.
option c: Lichen planus is a pruritic disease characterized by papules commonly seen over the flexor surfaces and trunk. oral and vulvovaginal lesions may also occur. oral lesions appear as lacy, white, and raised lesions.
option D: Diphtheria is characterized by the presence of a grey pseudomembrane covering the tonsils and pharynx. It is caused by corynebacterium diphtheriae.

question: zika virus is transmitted by:
options:
a) Aedes aegypti
b)culex
c)Anopheles
d)papatasii
solution:
zika virus is transmitted by the bite of infected Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus.

zika virus is an RNA virus belonging to the Flaviviridae group. The symptoms of zika virus
disease include fever, maculopapular rash, conjunctivitis, muscle and joint pain, malaise and
headache. These symptoms are mild and usually last for 2-7 days. It can be misdiagnosed as
dengue or influenza. In severe cases, it can lead to complications like Guillain-Barré syndrome, neuropathy, and myelitis.
zika virus infection during pregnancy may lead to microcephaly or congenital zika syndrome.

question: which of the following organisms causes disease following traumatic inoculation into the skin?
options:
a)sporothrix schenckii
b)Blastomyces dermatitidis
c)coccidioides immitis
d)paracoccidioides brasiliensis
solution:
Sporothrix schenckii causes infection followed by traumatic inoculation into the skin.
It is a dimorphic fungus that lives on vegetation such as grasses, trees, rose bushes, etc. Following traumatic inoculation into the skin as in thorn prick, S schenckii causes sporotrichosis, a chronic   granulomatous infection. This is usually further followed by spread along the draining lymphatics  and lymph nodes as shown in the image below.




subcutaneous mycoses are usually caused by traumatic inoculation of the causative fungus. These include:

question: Identify the class of immunoglobulin¦ shown in the image below.
options:
a)Ig A
b)Ig G
c)Ig M
d)Ig E
solution:
The above image shows a dimeric structure, characteristic of secretory IgA.
IgA immunoglobulin is the major antibody responsible for mucosal immunity. Its serum levels are usually low. It is predominantly present in the extravascular secretions. It is present in secretions  such as milk, saliva, and tears, and in secretions of the respiratory, intestinal, and genital tracts.
when present in the serum, it exists as a monomer similar to IgG. However, when it is secreted, it exists as a dimer. The dimeric structure consists of two monomers, which are stabilized by two
additional polypeptides:

• J chain, which stabilizes the molecule.
• secretory component, which is incorporated into the IgA when transported through the epithelial cell.

question: A 14-year-old boy presents with a history of vomiting within 3 hours of consumption of food at a party. which of the following organism is most likely to cause these symptoms?
options:
a)staphylococcus aureus
b)clostridium botulinum
c)clostridium perfringes
d)salmonella typhi
solution:
vomiting 2 hours after the consumption of food is likely food poisoning by staphylococcus
aureus.
staphylococcus aureus can grow in carbohydrate and protein food sources, producing
enterotoxins. There are 15 types, all of which are superantigens. They are preformed toxins that are relatively heat stable. They stimulate the vagus nerve,  vomiting centre of the brain and
intestinal peristaltic activity. Type A enterotoxin is responsible for most cases of food poisoning.
The common sources of infection are the foods that are not cooked after handling. These include sliced meats, puddings, pastries, and sandwiches. Ingestion of such contaminated food causes
food poisoning within 3o minutes to 6 hours after consumption. Patients present with nausea, vomiting, stomach cramps, and diarrhoea.

question: which of the following organisms produces superantigen?
options:
a)staphylococcus epidermidis
b)streptococcus pyogenes
c)Clostridium perfringens
d)vibrio cholera
solution:
streptococcus pyogenes produces streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxin (sPE), which is a superantigen.
superantigens are protein toxins that stimulate large numbers of T cells, irrespective of antigen  specificity. They bind to the class II MHC molecule outside the peptide-binding groove and vß    region of the TCR. some examples of superantigens are staphylococcal enterotoxins, toxic shock syndrome toxin, and group A streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxin.
The below image shows the binding of superantigen to T-cell receptor.

question:
A female patient who is from the north-eastern part of the country came to the hospital with complaints of progressive swelling of the upper limbs. she has a history of coronary artery     disease for which she underwent percutaneous coronary intervention. on examination, the    upper limbs are more swollen proximally than distally. what is the next best step in the
management of this patient?
options:
a)Echocardiography
b)Night blood test for worms
c)Duplex venous scan of limbs
d)ECG
solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of filariasis. The next best step would be to test the night blood for worms since the filarial species is nocturnally periodic (between 1o pm and 4 am) in
India.

question: which of the following helminthic infections, that is commonly transmitted by soil, is characterized by¦ the egg in stool as shown in the image below?
options:
a)Trichuris trichiura
b)Ancyclostoma duodenale
c)Necator americanus
d)Ascaris lumbricoides
solution:
The given image shows the egg of Trichuris trichiura (whipworm).
The characteristic features of whipworm eggs are:
• Barrel-shaped in the middle
• projecting colourless mucus plug at each pole
• contains an unsegmented ovum.
• Floast in the saturated salt solution.
• It has a triple shell. The outermost layer is stained brown.
Humans acquire infection by swallowing embryonated eggs in contaminated food or water.  The     eggs hatch in the small intestine, and the larvae produced pass into the cecum. The larvae become mature adults in 2-3 months. Adult females pass immature un-embryonated eggs in the stool.
Thus, diagnosis of whipworm infection is done by microscopic identification of the eggs in a stool specimen.
Most infections are asymptomatic. Moderate whipworm infection (2o adult worms or less), the worms are confined to the caecum and ascending colon. The symptoms include epigastric and
lower abdominal pain, diarrhoea (rarely bloody), vomiting, flatulence and distention, weight loss, and increased blood and iron loss. In heavy infections of 2oo adult worms or more - trichuriasis

dysentery syndrome -, the worms are in the distal colon and rectum. The symptoms include
bloody diarrhoea with profuse mucus, abdominal pain, tenesmus, weight loss leading to cachexia, severe anemia, and rectal prolapse. on examination, clubbing may be present. Blood
investigations may show moderate eosinophilia.
chronic infection leads to growth retardation and nutritional deficiencies. Around o.oo5 ml of   blood is lost per day per worm. In heavy infections, as much as 4 to 5 ml can be lost per day per worm. Treatment is mebendazole or albendazole.

question:
A 3o-year-old female from tribal area presented with fever for the last 3 days. on examination of the peripheral smear, a diagnosis of malaria was made. which of the following is most
likely to be the causative agent?
options:
a)P. falciparum
b)P. malariae
c)P. ovale
d)P. vivax
solution:
The image shows ring forms/ early trophozoites in erythrocyte, which are binucleate (double chromatin) resembling stereo headphones in appearance, characteristic of P. falciparum.
There may be several rings present within a single erythrocyte. The rings are often attached to the margins of the red cells and are described as form applique or accole.

question: The test kit shown in the image below works on the principle of:
options:
a)ELISA
b)Immunochromatography
c)Immunofluroscence
d)Chemiluminiscence
solution:
The above image shows a HbsAg card test kit which works on the principle
of immunochromatography.
In immunochromatography, a nitrocellulose membrane is used to absorb the antigen from a
specimen. The membrane is impregnated with anti-HBsAg antibody and colloidal gold dye. The specimen (serum) travels through the membrane by capillary action. If the serum contains
HBaAg, a coloured reaction (in the form of a band) appears directly on the membrane at the test site. These assays are rapid and include a built-in internal control.

question: A 22-year-old student presented with high-grade fever, and purpuric rash as shown in the image below. CSF sample showed gram-negative diplococci. which of the following is the  most likely aetiology?
options:
a)Neisseria meningitidis
b)pseudomonas aeruginosa
c)streptococcus pneumoniae
d)E.coli
solution:
This patient has a high-grade fever and is a student, so he presumably spends a lot of time in crowded areas. The above image shows a purpuric rash. This patient's features are seen in
meningococcemia caused by Neisseria meningitidis, which are gram-negative diplococci.
The organism enters the body through the nasopharynx by attaching to the epithelial cells with
the help of pili. From the nasopharynx, they enter the bloodstream producing bacteremia, and the symptoms may resemble upper respiratory tract infection.
Fulminant meningococcemia is the severe form, where the patient presents with high-grade fever and hemorrhagic rash. There is thrombosis of several small blood vessels in various organs with   perivascular infiltration and petechial hemorrhages. some patients with fulminant
meningococcemia may also develop disseminated intravascular coagulation, and circulatory collapse, a condition known as waterhouse–Friderichsen syndrome.

question: which of the following is the predominant pathogen to infect renal transplant recipients one to four months following transplantation?
options:
a)cytomegalovirus
b)Jc virus
c)BK virus
d)Epstein-Barr virus
solution:
The predominant pathogen to infect renal transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following the transplantation is cytomegalovirus (CMV).
CMV is the most common virus to affect recipients after organ transplantation (kidney, heart,
lung etc). The maximal risk occurs between 1 and 4 months after transplantation (in the absence    of prophylaxis). The most common CMV presentation in kidney transplant patients includes fever, leukopenia, hepatosplenomegaly, myalgia, and arthralgia. Antiviral prophylaxis with ganciclovir     or valganciclovir is used in renal transplant recipients whenever indicated to prevent CMV
disease.
Given below are the most common opportunistic infections in renal transplant recipients:

peritransplant (less than 1 m onth)	Early (1-6 months)	Late (more than 6 months)
wound infectionHerpes virus oral candidiasisurinary tract  infection	pneumocystis jiroveciCytome galovirusHepatitis BListeria	AspergillusNocardiaBk Virus (polyoma)Herpes zoster

question: which of the following is not true about Japanese encephalitis?
options:
a)Transmitted by culex vishnui
b)pig is the amplifier host
c)Man acts as the reservoir
d)vaccinating pigs is helpful in disease control
solution:
Humans are the dead-end hosts for the Japanese encephalitis virus.
Japanese encephalitis is an endemic viral infection transmitted by mosquitoes. There is an
increased risk in travelers to rural areas. JE has an inactivated vero culture-derived vaccine, given as 2 primary series to adults who are travelling to endemic areas.
other options:
option A: The disease is transmitted by Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui (common in India) species.

option B: Herons act as reservoir hosts and pigs as amplifier hosts.
option D: The control measures include mosquito control, locating piggeries away from the human dwellings and vaccinating pigs.
The image below shows the life cycle of the Japanese B encephalitis virus.

question: which of the following helps in bacterial adhesion?
options:
a)cytoplasmic membrane
b)Mesosomes
c)Fimbriae
d)Lipopolysaccharides
solution:
Fimbriae help in bacterial adhesion.
Fimbriae, also called pili, are hair-like surface appendage that projects from the cell surface as
straight filaments. They are primarily seen in Gram-negative bacteria. They are polymers of pilin. Fimbriae are classified based on the function as ordinary pili - for adhesion - and sex pili -
involved in bacterial conjugation. The functions of pili are given below:
• Bacterial conjugation through sex pili, which transfer of genetic material occurs.
• Bacterial adhesion of symbiotic and pathogenic bacteria to host cells using adhesins.
• Resistance to phagocytosis.
• Antigenic pilin proteins are responsible for the immune response.
• Twitching motility to bacteria.

question: which of the following is not involved in urethritis?
options:
a)Trichomonas
b)chlamydia
c)Gonococcus
d)H.ducreyi
solution:
Haemophilus ducreyi does not cause urethritis. It causes chancroid (soft chancre), which presents as a genital ulcer.
urethritis is classified into two types:
• Gonococcal urethritis - caused by Neisseria gonorrhoea.

• Non-gonococcal urethritis - caused by:
• chlamydia trachomatis (most common)
• ureaplasma urealyticum
• Adenovirus
• Haemophilus vaginalis
• Mycoplasma genitalium
• Tricomonas vaginalis (rare)
• Herpes simplex virus (rare)

question:
A 3o-year-old HIV-positive patient presented with a chronic history of watery diarrhea.
Histopathology of the ¦duodenum is shown in the image below. which of the following is the causative organism?
options:
a)Giardia lamblia
b)Entamoeba histolytica
c)Microsporidia
d)cryptosopridia
solution:
The histopathology shows trophozoites of Giardia lamblia in the duodenal lumen (marked in arrows).


• Giardia lamblia, also called Giardia duodenalis, is the causative agent of giardiasis. It is the only common pathogenic protozoan found in the duodenum and jejunum of humans.
• Infection is acquired by the consumption of water or food contaminated with cysts and may also be transmitted by the faeco-oral route.
• It is weakly pathogenic in humans. secretory IgA and IL-6 are responsible for clearing the infection. Hence, giardiasis usually occurs in immunosuppressed, agammaglobulinemia, or malnourished individuals.
• The symptoms include acute or chronic diarrhea, weight loss, malaise, abdominal cramps,
distension, and weakness. The stools may be watery, greasy, bulky, or foul-smelling at various times during the course of the infection.

• Histopathology of the duodenum reveals several heart-shaped or pear-shaped trophozoites with two equally sized nuclei. The small intestinal morphology is usually normal. However, in heavy     infections, there may be villous blunting and intraepithelial infiltrates.

question: what is the drug of choice for invasive pulmonary aspergillosis?
options:
a)Itraconazole
b)voriconazole
c)Lyophylised Amphotericin B
d)posaconazole
solution:
voriconazole is the drug of choice in the treatment of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis.
voriconazole can also be used against candida species (including glabrata and krusei),
scedosporium and Fusarium. The other options - itraconazole, posaconazole, lyophylised
Amphotericin B - can be used as alternatives for the treatment of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis if voriconazole is unavailable.

question: which of the following culture media is used to differentiate other E.coli species from E.coli o157: H7?
options:
a)Mannitol salt agar
b)Xylose lysine deoxycholate agar
c)sorbitol Macconkey agar
d)cLED medium
solution:
E.coli o157: H7 can be differentiated from other E.coli species using sorbitol Macconkey agar.
There are more than 15o serotypes of shiga toxin-producing E.coli (sTEc). of these, o157:H7 is
the most common type. Unlike most other E.coli serotypes, the sTEc o157:H7 does not use sorbitol and produces clear colonies on the sorbitol Macconkey agar.
o157: H7 strains also are negative for ß-glucuronidase using the substrate
4-methylumbelliferyl-ß-glucuronide (MUG) test. More than 9o per cent of other E.coli tests positive with this substrate.

question: A 5 year old boy was suffering from low grade fever, inspiratory stridor and barking cough for past 5 days. His chest X-ray is given below. what is the cause of this condition?
options:
a)Moraxella
b)parainfluenza
c)Hemophilus influenza
d)staphylococcus aureus
solution:
Barking cough is a feature of laryngotracheobronchitis, which is caused by the parainfluenza virus. The X-ray finding is the 'steeple sign' due to subglottic narrowing.
The age of presentation of laryngotracheobronchitis ranges from 6 months-6 years. The clinical features include barking cough, inspiratory stridor, hoarseness, low-grade fever.
Management:
• Racemic epinephrine nebulization leads to the rapid improvement of upper airway obstruction.   Epinephrine constricts pre-capillary arterioles in the upper airway mucosa and decreases capillary hydrostatic pressure, leading to fluid resorption and improvement in airway edema.
• Dexamethasone-by the least invasive route (oral>Iv>IM ). It is indicated in all the grades of croup.
• oxygen should be administered to children who are hypoxemic (spo2 <92 %) Antibiotics are not indicated in laryngotracheobronchitis.

question: which of the following is a bioterrorism category A agent?
options:
a)Nipah virus
b)Anthrax
c)coxiella
d)Brucella
solution: Bacillus anthracis which causes anthrax is categorized under category A bioterrorism agent.
